body: After two days of deliberations, the jury found former L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca guilty of obstruction of justice, conspiracy and lying.
title: Ex-LA County Sheriff Lee Baca found guilty in federal corruption scheme
caption: Former Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca (center) and his attorney Nathan Hochman (right) outside federal court in Los Angeles after a judge declared a mistrial in his first trial in December.

body: Prosecutors presented phone records, emails and other records and used closing arguments to try to draw clean lines to Baca. The defense tried to tangle them.
title: Closing arguments tell different tales of former sheriff
caption: Former Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca, second from right, leaves federal court in Los Angeles with attorneys Nathan Hochman, right, David Hochman and Baca's wife Carol after his corruption trial went to the jury Monday, March 13, 2017, in Los Angeles. Prosecution and defense attorneys finished closing remarks earlier Monday. (AP Photo/Nick Ut)

body: After a parade of prosecution witnesses that spanned nine days, Baca's attorney called just one witness, an attorney who provided independent oversight to sheriff's department. He testified Baca was communicative and cordial with the feds.
title: The defense calls a single witness
caption: Baca (center) and his attorney Nathan Hochman (right) outside a federal court in Los Angeles after a judge declared a mistrial in the obstruction of justice case against him. He's now being retried.

body: FBI special agent Leah Tanner walked the jury through her investigation into the L.A. County jails and how it ultimately took her to Lee Baca's door.
title: FBI agent: Conspiracy trail leads to former LA County Sheriff Lee Baca
caption: File: Former Sheriff Lee Baca stands behind his attorney Nathan Hochman on the steps of the federal courthouse. Baca has pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy, obstruction justice and lying.

body: The first week of testimony included multiple former sheriff's department employees, including an ex-captain who called Baca "the engine of the train."
title: Former employees testify against ex-Sheriff Baca in corruption trial
caption: File: Baca (center) and his attorney Nathan Hochman (right) outside a federal court in Los Angeles after a judge declared a mistrial in the obstruction of justice case against him. He's now being retried.

body: Prosecutors say Baca tried to block an FBI investigation into abusive deputies at the L.A. County jails. But the defense says their case falls short again.
title: Feds: Former LA County Sheriff Baca 'abused his power'
caption: File: Baca (center) and his attorney Nathan Hochman (right) outside a federal court in Los Angeles after a judge declared a mistrial in the obstruction of justice case against him. He's now being retried.

body: Baca will be retried on lying, corruption and obstruction of justice charges. Federal prosecutors successfully blocked him from using his early-onset Alzheimer's diagnosis in his defense at the upcoming corruption trial.
title: Judge: Former LA Sheriff Baca can't use Alzheimer's as defense
caption: Former L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca leaving the federal court with his attorneys. Baca is accused of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and lying to investigators.

body: The former L.A. sheriff is accused of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and lying in connection with a scheme to thwart an FBI investigation into the inmate abuse in the jails. A new trial is expected to begin this month, but Baca's attorneys won't be allowed to call character witnesses on his behalf.
title: Judge limits character witness testimony in upcoming Baca trial
caption: Baca (center) and his attorney Nathan Hochman (right) outside a federal court in Los Angeles after a judge declared a mistrial in the obstruction of justice case against him.

body: The Sheriff Civilian Oversight Commission, created to watchdog the sheriff's department, held its first meeting and heard about a range of concerns.
title: Era of civilian oversight begins at LA Sheriffs Department
caption: The Sheriff Civilian Oversight Commission conducted its first meeting at Patriotic Hall in downtown Los Angeles January 26, 2017, hearing concerns from police reform activists.

body: Baca was first tried on obstruction of justice and conspiracy charges last month, but the case ended in a mistrial because jurors could not come to a consensus. Eleven of the 12 wanted to acquit him on the charges. The new trial will begin Feb. 21.
title: Former LA Sheriff Lee Baca will be retried in corruption case
caption: Baca (center) and his attorney Nathan Hochman (right) outside a federal court in Los Angeles after a judge declared a mistrial in the obstruction of justice case against him.

body: The jury hearing the federal corruption case against former Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca told the judge Thursday afternoon that it is hopelessly deadlocked, postponing a resolution to a scandal that has plagued the nation's largest sheriff's department for years.
title: Deadlocked jury leads to mistrial

body: At the end of the federal corruption trial against former Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca, a federal prosecutor told the jury it was ultimately them who must “police the police.” Baca's attorney insited the actions were masterminded by then undersheriff Paul Tanaka and carried out in secret from the sheriff.
title: Baca trial wraps up
caption: Former L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca, center, leaves the federal courthouse on Wednesday, Dec. 14, 2016. His attorney, Nathan Hochman, is on his left.

body: After a judge rejected his initial guilty plea, Baca could have chosen to stick to his plea and be subject to whatever sentence was chosen. Instead, he withdraws his plea and opts for a jury trial, tentatively scheduled for September.
title: Baca chooses trial over prison

body: A federal judge rejected a plea deal for former L.A. Sheriff Baca, saying the deal with a maximum sentence of six months would trivialize the seriousness of his offenses.
title: Judge rejects Baca's plea deal as too lenient

body: Former L.A. County Undersheriff Paul Tanaka was convicted of obstruction of justice and conspiracy for attempting to thwart an investigation into jail violence.
title: Tanaka gets 5 years in prison, out as Gardena mayor
caption: Former Los Angeles County Undersheriff Paul Tanaka was sentenced to five years in federal prison for obstruction of justice and conspiracy.

body: Federal prosecutors want former L.A. Sheriff Lee Baca to serve six months in prison. Defense attorneys argue his Alzheimer's and reformer legacy warrant a lighter sentence.
title: Facing prison time, former Sheriff Baca discloses he has Alzheimer's

body: On trial for obstruction of justice himself now, former L.A. County Undersheriff Paul Tanaka repeats his claim that it wasn't his idea to hide a jail informant from federal handlers.
title: Tanaka takes witness stand again — this time in his own defense
caption: File: Paul Tanaka, seen here as he prepared to testify in front of the Citizens Commission on Jail Violence in 2012.

body: Baca pleaded guilty Wednesday to lying to federal investigators looking into abuses in county jails. More than a dozen officials and deputies have been swept up in the probe.
title: Former LA Sheriff Lee Baca pleads guilty to federal charges

body: Tom Carey, a former L.A. County Sheriff captain, is accused of hiding an FBI jailhouse informant to impede a federal investigation into abuse by guards.
title: Ex-sheriff's captain pleads guilty in corruption case
caption: Tom Carey, a former L.A. County Sheriff captain, is accused of hiding an FBI jailhouse informant to impede a federal investigation into abuse by guards.

body: A Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy pleaded guilty Tuesday in a case involving the beating of a handcuffed man who had been visiting his brother in jail.
title: LA County deputy pleads guilty in jail case
caption: L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca conducts an inspection of Men's Central Jail in Downtown Los Angeles in this photo from December 2011.

body: Paul Tanaka, who once ran operations at the Los Angeles Sheriff's Department, "perpetuated a gang-like mentality among some in rank and file," an FBI official said.
title: Feds indict former Tanaka in LA jails scandal
caption: Paul Tanaka, seen here in a file photo as he prepared to testify in front of the Citizens Commission on Jail Violence in 2012, was expected to be indicted Thursday, May 14, 2015, along with a former captain, for obstruction of justice, according to a source familiar with the investigation.

body: Former Long Beach police chief Jim McDonnell promised a fresh start for the troubled L.A. Sheriff's office after taking the oath of office Monday as its 32nd leader.
title: New sheriff calls for fresh start
caption: Shortly after his swearing in, new L.A. Sheriff Jim McDonnell said he's happy to hear about the White House's plan to use federal funding to supply body cameras to officers.

body: Six deputies convicted federal court for obstructing an FBI investigation into the L.A. County jails were sentenced Tuesday to a minimum of two years prison.
title: LA sheriff's deputies in FBI obstruction case get moderate prison sentences
caption: Defendant Scott Craig walks out of court Tuesday. He was sentenced to 33 months in prison.

body: Former Undersheriff Paul Tanaka takes the stand as a witness in the obstruction of justice trial against six deputies. He tells a jury he never ordered deputies to hide an FBI informant, but agreed with their actions.
title: Former Undersheriff Tanaka testifies in federal misconduct trial
caption: LA sheriff's candidate Paul Tanaka answers questions after testifying in a deputy misconduct trial in federal court.

body: Embattled Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca announced his plans to retire at the end of the month at a press conference Tuesday morning.
title: Baca announces plans to retire
caption: Sheriff Lee Baca at a press conference Jan. 7, 2014 where he announced his plans to retire.

body: The U.S. Department of Justice unsealed five cases that charge 18 current or former members of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department with a wide range of crimes — 38 charges in all. Sheriff Lee Baca called it a "sad day" and added that the department has been fully cooperative with the investigation.
title: 18 current and former LA Sheriff's deputies charged in jail abuse case
caption: Los Angeles Sheriff Lee Baca at a press conference responding to the F.B.I. arrests of 17 Los Angeles sheriff's deputies.

body: In an unusual decision, a federal jury in Los Angeles has found Sheriff Lee Baca personally liable for the excessive use of force against an inmate at Men’s Central Jail. Baca will personally pay $100,000 in punitive damages.
title: Baca financially liable in jail inmate abuse case

body: Paul Tanaka, the No. 2 executive in the L.A. County Sheriff's Department, becomes an outspoken critic of the department.
title: LA County Undersheriff Paul Tanaka offers harsh criticism of Baca
caption: Undersherrif Paul Tanaka prepares to testify in front of the Citizens Commission on Jail Violence on Friday, July 27, 2012. The commission was formed by the LA County Board of Supervisors to investigate allegations of abuse at county jails.

body: Baca's Twitter arrival comes as the Sheriff’s Department struggles with grim publicity over the last year — from deputy abuse of inmates in the county jails, to off-duty deputies behaving badly, to accusations of department nepotism.
title: Facing onslaught of bad publicity, Baca joins Twitter
caption: LA County Sheriff Lee Baca has joined Twitter and is now writing a blog on the L.A. Sheriff's Department website.

body: Although under fire for jailhouse abuses, Baca was picked as the nation's Sheriff of the Year.
title: Baca named national 'Sheriff of the Year'

body: Seven Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies have been notified that the department intends to fire them for being members of a secret law enforcement clique that celebrated shootings and branded its members with matching tattoos, the Los Angeles Times reported.
title: After scandal, Baca moves to fire deputies in Jump Out Boys clique

body: Under mounting political pressure to reform L.A. County jails, and after the board put in place a compliance monitor to track his progress. Baca said he would implement the new reforms, with or without crucial funding, and that a new force policy will be released in January.
title: Baca responds to criticism over jail violence
caption: Sheriff Lee Baca at a press conference at the Los Angeles Sheriffs Department June 8, 2007 in Monterey Park, California.

body: The U.S. Supreme Court turned down L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca’s petition to stop an inmate from suing him over a jail stabbing, setting the stage for the lawsuit to go forward.
title: Jail-stabbing suit against Baca moves forward
caption: Los Angeles County Sheriff Lee Baca in 2010

body: LA County sheriff's detectives launch probe into what appears to be a secret deputy clique within the department's elite gang unit, an investigation triggered by the discovery of a document suggesting the group embraces shootings as a badge of honor, the Los Angeles Times reported.
title: Secret clique in LA County Sheriff's gang unit probed
caption: A tattoo featured on a number of sheriff's clique members allegedly glamorized jailhouse violence

body: Sheriff Lee Baca briefly considered closing part of Men's Central Jail in downtown Los Angeles after a federal investigation was announced into alleged deputy brutality in L.A. county jails.
title: Baca considers shutting part of Men's Central Jail after abuse allegations
caption: Los Angeles County Men's Central Jail

body: The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California filed a federal civil rights lawsuit that accuses Sheriff Lee Baca of failing to stop a “pattern and practice of deputy-on-inmate violence” inside L.A. County jails.
title: ACLU files federal lawsuit against Sheriff Baca over jail abuse
caption: L.A. County Sheriff Lee Baca conducts an inspection of Men's Central Jail in Downtown Los Angeles in this photo from December 2011.

body: Immigrant rights groups sue Baca in an effort to force him to hand over information about his cooperation with federal immigration authorities.
title: Immigrants rights groups sue Baca

body: Baca said he'll release non-violent inmates with minimal criminal histories earlier than planned to help the county address a $400 million budget shortfall.
title: Baca seeks early release of inmates

body: Elected by the citizens of Los Angeles County, Sheriff Lee Baca began leading the largest Sheriff's Department in the United States and supervising more than 13,000 sworn and civilian personnel.
title: Sheriff Baca sworn in as LA County's 30th Sheriff

body: Lee Baca saw himself as an advocate of education. He earned his Bachelor's degree in 1971 from California State University, Los Angeles, a Master of Public Administration in 1973, and later received his Doctorate of Public Administration in 1993 from the University of Southern California School of Policy, Planning, and Development.
title: Baca graduates from USC

body: After serving as commander of numerous stations, Lee Baca was promoted to the rank of Chief by then Sheriff Sherman Block.
title: Baca promoted to Chief Deputy

body: Early on in his career, Baca worked in custody, recruitment, on patrol on the streets of East Los Angeles and as instructor at the Sheriff's Academy. Throughout his time at the sheriff's department, he rose through the ranks — from commander all the way to chief in 1992.
title: Lee Baca sworn in as a deputy sheriff trainee at the Los Angeles Sheriff's Department
Baca enters the United States Marine Corps Reserves
